intro: Sida maculata, commonly known as the spotted sida, is a flowering plant native to the Americas. It is a herbaceous annual or biennial species that typically grows in dry, disturbed soils. The plant features small, white to pale purple flowers that bloom in clusters, and its leaves are often speckled with dark spots, giving it its common name. Sida maculata is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. It is often found in grasslands, fields, and along roadsides, where it thrives in full sun.
